title: 'We have liftoff': Crane lifts massive Civil War painting
text:
By Phil Gast , CNN Updated 0315 GMT (1115 HKT) February 10, 2017 
Chat with us in Facebook Messenger. Find out what's happening in the world as it unfolds. A portion of the panoramic painting is loaded onto a truck for transport. Story highlights Portion of giant painting is lifted from building "Battle of Atlanta" will be restored, presented in new building elsewhere in Atlanta Atlanta (CNN) To a chorus of cheers, one half of a massive painting depicting a major Civil War battle was lifted by crane Thursday night for the trip to its new home, where it will be carefully restored. Why is the "Battle of Atlanta" being moved in halves? The 1886 work is so big -- weighing about five tons and 371 feet long -- that conservators cut it in two and wrapped it around two 45-foot metal spools for transport to the Atlanta History Center, 12 miles away from its longtime Grant Park home. "We have liftoff," uttered someone in the small crowd that huddled on a cold winter evening to watch the lift of the first spool. The description seems appropriate, given that the shrink-wrapped spools do appear to be miniature rockets. Officials had hoped to remove both spools on Thursday from the now-shuttered Atlanta Cyclorama & Civil War Museum. Read More But problems with proper attachment of a base plate delayed the operation, so only one was lifted Thursday and put on a flatbed truck for the journey. The second will come out Friday; both should be in their new home by later in the day. Sheffield Hale, president and chief executive officer at the Atlanta History Center, said Thursday "was a red-letter day for history." He said the "wow factor" will return to the painting in its new home. And it has to be seen in person to be truly appreciated, he said. "It's real, something they can't see at home or on a (computer) screen," Hale said. The "Battle of Atlanta" was created by German artists during the heyday of paintings called cycloramas, and only a few still exist in North America. The 360-degree renderings of landscapes, city skylines and war were popular before movies came on the scene. This painting depicts the July 1864 Battle of Atlanta during the Civil War. The painting was intended as a tribute to a Northern victory but, perhaps ironically, it ended up in the South. While the Atlanta artwork is irreplaceable, the history center has insured it for $7.5 million. The focal point of the sprawling painting is fierce fighting around a house, with Confederates firing from behind cotton bales. Federal troops and cavalry are rushing toward that point and are on the cusp of victory. The fall of Atlanta more than a month later helped re-elect President Abraham Lincoln. Over the years, the painting began to shows it age, and the roof continues to leak during rainstorms. Observers worried the old building was contributing to the painting's slow deterioration. A recent visit to the brick-walled, circular room showed some water seepage on the floor. By 2014, attendance at the Atlanta Cyclorama & Civil War Museum was was mostly in decline. Zoo Atlanta, which sits next door in the city's Grant Park neighborhood, wanted to expand. A crane lifts a spool holding one half of the 19th century painting What to do? A decision was made to move the city-owned painting into a new building at the Atlanta History Center The painting, made of Belgian linen, will be restored at its new home in the Buckhead neighborhood before an autumn 2018 opening. Trying to immerse viewer in the scene Officials say the painting will be presented in the way its creators originally intended. That's partially because parts of the painting were cut over the years. In 1921, the installation crew at Grant Park had a wee bit of a problem -- the painting was too big for the building. The solution? Lop off a 6-foot-wide section of the battle scene (fortunately, near an entrance tunnel). The "Battle of Atlanta" also lost nearly 8 feet of sky over the years as workers installed it in different buildings. The painting, with an accompanying diorama, shows the Battle of Atlanta on July 22, 1864. Conservators will restore those missing pieces. The painting also will have the proper perspective: Until now, the work hung like a shower curtain and there were folds and creases. The aim is to return the "immersion" effect. And the "Battle of Atlanta" will be displayed in its original hyperbolic, or hourglass shape. Through proper tension at the top and bottom, the painting's horizon will appear closer to the viewer, restoring the original 3D illusion.
